editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Hapned the 27. day of March, Stilo Romano la≈øt, at Callabria, in the Kingdome of Naples, about the houres of three and foure in the afternoone, to the over-throw and ruine of many Cities, Townes, and Ca≈øtles, and the death of above fifty thou≈øand per≈øons.

div.head: A True RELATION OF A GREAT and violent Earthquake happened in Callabria the 27. of March, 1638. Stilo Romano, to the overthrow of Eight great Cities, Twenty foure Townes, and about fifty Thou≈øand per≈øons.
div.p:
I Have oftentimes con≈øidered with my ≈øelfe in the depth of my ≈øerious Meditations, the mo≈øt remarkable Prodigies, and Accidents that have happened ≈øince the Birth of our Saviour
Chri≈øt, to this very Time wherein wee now are: and though I confe≈ø≈øe, that old Authors have left them to us in the writings both terrible and fearefull, and ≈øo horrid to the Learned of tho≈øe times, and to the Aged of tho≈øe dayes, that it afforded them matter and Subiect ≈øufficient of relating and writing the ≈øame to the Ages and Times that ≈øhall ≈øucceed them, and were accompanied with ≈øuch terrours to tho≈øe that then were the Eye-witne≈ø≈øes thereof, that the ≈øame cau≈øed them to be, as the Scripture hath it, at their wits end, and tooke from them as then, all manner of life and motion, bringing therewith to tho≈øe that onely heard thereof, though farre di≈øtant, both a wonderfull amazement and an exceeding a≈øtoni≈øhment, both of body and minde: the mo≈øt notable that have beene ob≈øerved, have fallen out and happen'd contrary to the u≈øuall and common cour≈øe of Nature, as
the apparition of many Sunnes at one and the ≈øelfe-≈øame in≈øtant of time, and that happened in the yeere of our Lord 64. and in the yeere of our Lord 438. be≈øides the three Sunnes that appeared and was manife≈øted to the view of all beholders, wherein the figure of a naked Mon≈øter appeared, who≈øe body bore three Heads of humane forme. The ≈øaid ≈øtrange Accidents in the Firmament by the apparition of many Sunnes was al≈øo ≈øeene in the yeeres 1429, 1452, and 1480. accompanied alwayes with horrible Tempe≈øts, cruell Lightnings, and with violent Thundrings and rumors in the Ayre. Be≈øides which, at other times were ≈øeene Dragons with three Heads, with many Ba≈øilisks and flying Serpents, combatting and fighting again≈øt Armies of Hor≈øe and Foote, as in the yeeres of our Lord 984. and 995. At other times al≈øo were ≈øeene fiery Pillars of immea≈øurable greatne≈ø≈øe and
length, the mo≈øt remarkable of which happened Twelve yeeres after the comming of our Redeemer Chri≈øt Je≈øus, and ≈øo al≈øo the ≈øame in the yeeres of 372. 1560. and 1569.

Againe, at one and the ≈øelfe-≈øame time were ≈øeene flying Bafilisks and ≈øiery Pillars, as in the yeeres of our Lord 1585. and oftentimes have been ≈øeene Swords, Darts, and other Martiall Weapons; and armed Hor≈øe and Foote-men which have combatted together, and have beene ≈øeene the one ≈øide to overthrow and put to rout the other, as in the yeere of our Lord 71. and in the yeere 1526.

In the I≈øland of Cyprus, now under the Subiection of the Grand Turke, in the yeere of our Lord 78. did appeare in the Firmament, to the terrour of the beholders, Foure men of a large ≈øtature and greatne≈ø≈øe, cloathed with Fire, and armed with horrible Darts, and Comets: Likewi≈øe it is recorded
that in Con≈øtantinople, the Metropolis of the pre≈øent Empire of the Turkes, in the yeere of our Lord 432. it powred downe or hailed (if I may ≈øo tearme it) a ≈øtorme of Stones: and in the City of Tolledo in Spaine in the ≈øame yeere was ≈øeene in the Ayre ≈øtrange Diabolicall figures and ≈øhapes, which moved much the beholders both to feare and horrour.

At other times have beene al≈øo ≈øeene many Cro≈ø≈øes in the Firmament, ≈øometimes to the number of Seven and Eight, with fiery Comets, accompanied with other prodigies, and this happened in the yeere of our Lord, 1228. and 1321. and in conclu≈øion to avoid prolixity in the recounting and numbring of ≈øo many ≈øtrange and terrible Accidents, (that Marble it ≈øelfe would be affraid if it were any way capable of feare and frighting) To ≈øee it raine a quantity of humane Corps, and to fall from the Skies to the number of
two Hundred in one place, would doubtle≈ø≈øe affright the mo≈øt hardy and undaunted courage of the mo≈øt re≈øolute and valiant: and what living Soule would not be affraid thereat? and this happened in the yeere 570. in Italy, and ≈øome yeeres after in the Kingdome of France.

In our times to heare of Earthquakes, and ≈øee the motion and removall of the Land in this or in that part of the World, to ≈øee the Ayre infected, to feele the contagious Plague and Pe≈øtilence, and to under≈øtand of the great Mortality of Mankind is ordinary: to heare the Stones of that flaming and evaporating Hill Ve≈øuvius neare the City of Naples, ≈øome yeeres pa≈øt, who thru≈øt and belched from its bowells ≈øuch abundance of flame, ≈ømoake, and a≈øhes, with ≈øo much hurt, harme, and univer≈øall preiudice to the poore neighbouring Inhabitants, and to the Citizens of that flouri≈øhing City is
every where publi≈øhed. I therefore willingly here omit the Relation of tho≈øe other remarkable & memorable Earthquakes which have happened in ≈øundry parts, and divers Kingdomes of the World, which though they are confe≈ø≈øed to be great, and horrid, and accompanied with the Mortality and Death of many per≈øons, yet notwith≈øtanding the terrour thereof, the ≈øame hath not ≈øo much daunted and amazed the hearts and courages of men as this now late Earthquake hath done, that happened the 27. day of March la≈øt, 1638. according to the Romane Account, about the Houres of 21. and 22. according to their Computation; and according to the Engli≈øh the 17. of March, 1637. and betweene Three and Foure of the Clocke in the Afternoone, being Saturday, and accounted the Fea≈øt-day of Saint Patricke the Iri≈øh Saint, in the Province of Callabria the Inferiour, part of the notable and
plentifull Countrey and Kingdome of Naples, which hath proved ≈øo univer≈øall a ≈øcourge to that Province, and unto that part of the Countrey, that the Tongue of Man cannot po≈ø≈øibly recount the ≈øame, nor the lea≈øt part of the affliction which that mi≈øerable people, the Inhabitants which are yet remaining thereabouts, have ≈øuffered: what ≈øudden and unexpected ≈øuffocations by water did ≈øome endure! What openings of the Earth were ≈øeene, where the bodies of ≈øome were in part or in whole impri≈øon'd and ≈øtifled! how many are di≈øtraught with the terrour of the motions of the Hills and Mountaines! and how many ≈ølain and ruin'd with the fall of their Habitations and Man≈øions! how many he cover'd now in Death with that covering, which in Life defended them by Night and Day both from the Summers Sun and the Winters cold! how many were within doores ≈ølaine, before they
could get out, and how many peri≈øhed in the fields ere they could returne to their Cities and Hou≈øes. The husband was a≈øwell unmindfull of his deare≈øt Wife, as the tender Mother was of her neare≈øt and deare≈øt Children: The Ma≈øter commanded in vaine; and the Servant had no time to obey for feare of death: ≈øome ranne to the Hou≈øe tops for ≈øafety, and ≈øome to their Vaults and Sellers, yet both found their ruine alike: ≈øo that tho≈øe horrours this Earthquake was accompanyed with, attended upon the inhabitants both at home and abroad, both within their doores, and abroad in their fields; here was no lea≈øure for to ≈øend for a Prie≈øt, nor no time for admini≈øtration of the Sacrament; but onely that is in Chri≈øtian Charity to be beleeved, that every one be≈øeeched the pitty and goodne≈ø≈øe of the Almighty and mo≈øt mercifull God for pardon for
their ≈øinnes, who though he ≈øometimes in Iu≈øtice cha≈øti≈øeth and ≈øcourgeth, yet willeth notwith≈øtanding our totall perdition, and e≈øpecially of ≈øo many ≈øoules redeemed by the power of his precious blood, and by him ≈øo dearely loved.

We then, like loving Children towards ≈øo gracious and good a Father, with corre≈øpondent ≈øincere affection, and pure hearts, ought alwaies ≈øo to live, as to be prepared for ≈øuch, or the like ≈øuddaine accidents and dangers, having recour≈øe to the foote≈øtoole of his mercy Seate, imploring there his aide, helpe, and protection, and flying and avoyding all occa≈øions of offending ≈øo gracious and mercifull a God, who is bent ever to puni≈øh the wicked, and to be merciful to the iu≈øt and penitent, thereby mitigating his iu≈øt wrath and vengeance, the which by how much it is for-flowed, is by ≈øo much the more to bee feared to increa≈øe.

And now becau≈øe that from Me≈ø≈øina in Sicilia, and from Co≈ø≈øen≈øa in Apulia, the generality of the≈øe accidents is come unto us, I have thought it fitting to nominate the principall and chiefe of the≈øe Cities, Townes, Ca≈øtles, and Signories which have ≈øuffer'd, and are ruin'd and de≈øtroyed by this ≈øo great and heavy a ≈øcourge, wereby every man may re≈øt truely and really ≈øatisfied with the certainty thereof.

div.head: The names of the Principall Cities and Ca≈øtles de≈øtroyed by the Earth-quake are the≈øe, &c.
div.p: THe City of Nicastero, which is wholly de≈øtroyed and ruined downe to the ground.
The City of Monterane al≈øo wholly de≈øtroyed.

The City of Ca≈øtalione wholly de≈øtroyed: the Prince thereof

The famous City of Co≈ø≈øen≈øa,is the one halfe ruined and de≈øtroyed,with the Countrey-hou≈øes thereabouts in the territory adjoyning; al≈øo the Palace of the Prince, the famous Convent of the Je≈øuites, and the much noted Convent of the Capuchin Friers.
A great part of the City of Poala.

The towne of Macdo but in part.

The towne of Sancta Nico≈øia, drowned, with the Neighbouring Country for five miles circute bordering upon the Sea≈øhoare, and many
others of le≈ø≈øer note and con≈øequence, not yet come to our true knowledge.

In the≈øe Cities and Townes it is reported that there is Dead, Lo≈øt, Drowned, and ≈øuncke into the Earth, about fifty thou≈øand per≈øons, and that there was counted in the≈øe places twenty ≈øix thou≈øand Families great and ≈ømall: the ≈øaid Earth-quake having at that one in≈øtant of time ≈øpread it ≈øelfe for the circuite of three≈øcore and ten miles in compa≈ø≈øe, and pa≈ø≈øed from Callabra over the Phare of Me≈øsina, to that Citty where the Belfree was ≈øhaken, and fell upon the roofe of the principall Church thereof, breaking downe the ≈øame, with the death of many then at their devotion in the ≈øaid Church: The Arch-bi≈øhop and Vicar of the ≈øaid City, with divers other Church-men, who at that in≈øtant of time were walking neare at hand in a Garden belonging unto the ≈øame, were thereby freed and ≈øaved from that pre≈øent danger, and that ≈øome al≈øo of the inhabitants of
the≈øe above named Cities, ≈øaved them≈øelves by flying away into the fields, and by many other ≈øtrange and unheard of accidents.

Many other particular reports are ≈øpread abroad through Italy of this feareful, heavy, and ≈øuddaine iudgement, which wee will forbeare to nominate, de≈øiring Almighty God of his goodne≈ø≈øe to ble≈ø≈øe us, and pre≈øerve us, and all men, from the≈øe, and the like ≈øuch dangerous incounters, Amen.
